review:
Alright, let's cut through the noise and get to the alpha. Open to the Public (OTTP) is gunning for a foundational layer in the Ethereum ecosystem: a decentralized, onchain work/collaboration graph. Think LinkedIn meets EAS, but you own your data, your creds, and your rep. This is a big swing at a root problem—work contributions are siloed, unverifiable, and locked in walled gardens. OTTP wants to break those walls, let users and orgs own their work graph, and make it portable across dApps and chains. That’s a high-impact, systemic play—right in the sweet spot for max utility.

The project is open source, leverages EAS, and is already live with an SDK (1.3K+ downloads—solid traction for infra). The roadmap is ambitious but clear: SDK v2, web client, account abstraction, and governance. They’re building for scale, not just a niche. The protocol design is modular and composable, with a focus on interoperability and user sovereignty. That’s the kind of infra that can become a standard if executed well.

On the innovation front, OTTP is layering attestations on top of EAS to create a verifiable, portable work graph. That’s a novel approach—no one else is doing this at this scale or with this level of composability. The team is experienced, has shipped before, and is building in public. They’re using funds for dev bounties—maximizing output, minimizing overhead. That’s lean, efficient, and aligns with open-source capitalist values.

But let’s not get too bullish without some FUD-checking. The biggest gap: metrics. While they track user and attestation counts, there’s no hard data on active usage, retention, or real-world integrations. The roadmap is ambitious, but timelines are aggressive and lack detail on risk mitigation. There’s also a dependency on EAS—if EAS stumbles, OTTP could get rekt. Finally, while the vision is big, there’s not enough detail on how they’ll drive adoption beyond the dev crowd.

Bottom line: OTTP is swinging for the fences on systemic, scalable infra. It’s high-upside, high-risk. If they hit, it’s a game-changer for onchain work and collaboration. But they need to tighten up their metrics, adoption strategy, and risk management to really lock in that max utility. Build in public, but show us the numbers and the plan to get to network effects. That’s how you disrupt the system and win.

strengths.title: Systemic, Scalable Infrastructure
strengths.description: OTTP targets a root problem—siloed, unverifiable work contributions—and proposes a protocol that could become a standard for onchain collaboration. This aligns perfectly with the round’s focus on foundational Ethereum infra and maximizes long-term impact.

strengths.title: Open Source, Modular, and Composable
strengths.description: The protocol is open source, modular, and designed for interoperability. This enables broad adoption, customization, and integration across the ecosystem, supporting maximal scale and utility.

strengths.title: Strong Team and Public Track Record
strengths.description: The team has shipped live products, participated in multiple Gitcoin rounds, and builds in public. The SDK has 1.3K+ downloads, showing real traction and community interest.

strengths.title: Efficient Use of Funds
strengths.description: Funds are earmarked for development bounties, maximizing output and minimizing bureaucratic overhead. This is a lean, high-leverage approach that fits open-source capitalist principles.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Detailed Usage Metrics
weaknesses.description: While the project tracks some metrics (downloads, attestations), there’s no clear data on active users, retention, or integrations. This makes it hard to assess real-world impact and adoption.

weaknesses.title: Ambitious Roadmap with Limited Risk Mitigation
weaknesses.description: The roadmap is aggressive but lacks detail on how risks (technical, adoption, EAS dependency) will be managed. There’s also little info on how they’ll drive adoption beyond the developer community.

weaknesses.title: Dependency on Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS)
weaknesses.description: OTTP’s reliance on EAS introduces a single point of failure. If EAS faces issues, OTTP’s core functionality could be compromised.

changes.title: Provide Detailed Usage and Adoption Metrics
changes.description: Include data on active users, retention rates, and real-world integrations. Show how the protocol is being used beyond SDK downloads to demonstrate actual impact.

changes.title: Expand on Adoption and Go-to-Market Strategy
changes.description: Detail how you plan to drive adoption outside the dev community. What’s the plan to onboard DAOs, orgs, and mainstream users? How will you achieve network effects?

changes.title: Address EAS Dependency Risks
changes.description: Outline contingency plans if EAS becomes unavailable or deprecated. How will OTTP maintain functionality or migrate attestations in such a scenario?
